Popular Music Resources

Databases, special collections, and general resources on the history of popular music

Links

  • WorldCat UMD
    WorldCat UMD is a discovery tool that searches libraries worldwide and allows you to search multiple high quality sources at one time. You can begin your search on the Library homepage or click the link above.
    You can enter an author, title, ISBN or combination of these in the search box to find a specific book. If the patron needs a certain edition of a book, be sure to click the "Editions and Formats" link and sort by Library to see everything we have.
    If a book is not available at College Park, but is at another campus in the University System of Maryland, the patron can click "Request" and choose the USM campus where the book should be delivered. Interlibrary Loan is for those books that are only at "WorldCat Libraries," which may take more time.
  • Rock's Backpages
  • SCPA Keesing Collection
  • SCPA Punk Fanzines
  • AAA - Music Index (EBSCO)
    [mobile version]##The Music Index, produced by Harmonie Park Press, is the single most comprehensive subject-author guide to music periodical literature. The Music Index has been available in print since 1949. The Music Index online coverage spans from 1976 to the present and contains surveyed data from 775 international music periodicals from over 40 countries, with English translations from 22 languages.
  • AAA - RILM Abstracts of Music Literature (EBSCO)
    [mobile version]##An international bibliography of nearly 500,000 scholarly writings on music and related disciplines in 140 languages. RILM indexes articles, books, conference proceedings, bibliographies, catalogues, dissertations, festchriften, iconographies, critical commentaries to complete works, ethnographic recordings and videos, reviews and more.

Reference books

  • The Billboard Book of Top 40 Hits by Joel Whitburn
    Call Number: REF ML156.4.P6 W44 2004
    ISBN: 9780823074990
    Publication Date: 2004-07-01
    Provides complete, cross-referenced information for all songs and artists to make the Top Forty of Billboard's Hot 100 singles chart from 1955 to today. One of several Billboard discographies at the library.
  • Encyclopedia of Great Popular Song Recordings by Steve Sullivan
    Call Number: REF ML156.4.P6 S87 2013
    ISBN: 9780810882959
    Publication Date: 2013-10-04
    Explores 1,000 key song recordings from 1889 to the present, unveiling the stories behind the songs, the recordings, the performers, and the songwriters.

There are many discographies and guides to research in the reference section of the Performing Arts Library. Here are a few that may be especially useful.

  • Blues, Funk, Rhythm and Blues, Soul, Hip Hop, and Rap by Eddie S. Meadows
    Call Number: REF ML128.P63 M43 2010
    ISBN: 9780415973199
    Publication Date: 2010-06-10
    A bibliography and research guide for African American music and culture.
  • The Green Book of Songs by Subject by Jeff Green
    Call Number: ML156.4.P6 G73 2002
    ISBN: 0939735105
    Publication Date: 2002-07-01
    Indexes songs by subject, covering popular hits, country music, soul, jazz, big band, Broadway musicals, and motion picture soundtracks. A truly one-of-a-kind resource.

Introduction

Welcome, pop music researchers! The Performing Arts Library has a variety of resources to help you with your research project, including databases, articles, books, CDs, and some unique primary sources. 

Below you'll find a brief description of some of the tools that may be most helpful to you. The box on the left has some quick links to these resources.

Books and recordings at the library

The Performing Arts Library contains thousands of books, CDs, DVDs, and other materials on all genres of music, including popular music. Enter your search terms in the library catalog, WorldCat UMD. On the lefthand side of the search results page, you will be able to limit by format.

You can check out up to three CDs at a time for one week.

Finding articles

The library subscribes to a number of databases that can help you locate articles related to the history of popular music.

  • Music Index Online is an index to literature on all genres of music, including popular genres. It tends to cover more popular music magazines like Spin or Rolling Stone. So Music Index is a good place to check for non-scholarly but reputable sources. More information about how to search Music Index is available in this library guide.
  • For scholarly articles about music, RILM is probably your best bet. Although it focuses more on classical music, RILM also includes many sources on jazz and popular music. It includes journal articles, dissertations, book chapters, and more.
  • Rock's Backpages is a database of more than 25,000 articles since 1960. It covers music journalism about all genres of popular music: rock, pop, soul, hip-hop, folk, and much more. You'll find features, interviews, album reviews, and commentaries from hundreds of publications, as well as over 400 audio interviews. You can browse by genre or publication, or search for your favorite artist. This library guide explains the database in more detail.

Tip: The "Quick search" box in the upper left of this guide will let you run a basic search in Music Index and RILM at the same time.

Special collections in popular music

You can find collections of rare or unique materials at Special Collections in the Performing Arts (SCPA), located inside the Performing Arts Library. A few collections might be especially interesting to popular music researchers:

  • The Keesing Collection on Popular Music and Culture contains books, recordings, serials, memorabilia, and other collector's items related to 20th-century American popular music, especially rock and roll from the 1950s and 1960s. It includes particularly strong collections about Elvis Presley, The Beatles, Fats Domino, and Roy Orbison. 

  • The D.C. Punk and Indie Fanzine Collection includes rare publications created by fans of and participants in the punk and indie music scenes of the Washington, D.C. area from the late 1970s to the present. The collection is strongest in its coverage of fanzines from the 1990s. These items can give you a unique glimpse into the local indie music scene.
